author: By Salman Masood
title: Pakistan’s Prime Minister Links Rape to ‘Vulgarity’ and How Women Dress
description: Activists have accused Prime Minister Imran Khan of “baffling ignorance” and victim-blaming after he said rape cases had risen because of “vulgarity.”
content: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — An outcry has erupted in Pakistan after Prime Minister Imran Khan blamed a rise in rape cases on how women dressed, remarks that activists denounced as perpetuating a culture of victim blaming.

title: Why Students Are Logging In to Class From 7,000 Miles Away
description: Students are joining remote classes from outside the country. In one New Jersey school district, computers were traced to 24 countries on a day last month.
content: Faiqa Naqvi, a 15-year-old freshman at a New Jersey public high school, logs in to her all-remote classes each night from Pakistan in a time zone nine hours ahead.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anne Mancuso and Lisa Prevost
title: Homes for Sale in New York and Connecticut

author: By Heather Murphy
title: Vaccinated Mothers Are Trying to Give Babies Antibodies via Breast Milk
description: Multiple studies show that there are antibodies in a vaccinated mother’s milk. This has led some women to try to restart breastfeeding and others to share milk with friends’ children.
content: As soon as Courtney Lynn Koltes returned home from her first Covid-19 vaccine appointment, she pulled out a breast pump. She had quit breastfeeding her daughter about two months earlier because of a medication conflict. But she was off those pills, and she had recently stumbled across research suggesting that antibodies from a vaccinated mother could be passed to her baby through milk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Philip Galanes
title: Should I Have Spoken Up?
description: A reader wonders what she could have done to stop some troubling behavior she saw at a vaccine site.
content: While waiting in a long line to get my Covid-19 vaccination, I noticed two boisterous white men ahead of me. At first I chalked up their noise to excitement. But as I waited, I realized they were harassing an older Black woman who was in line in front of them. They were crowding her and telling her to move up, even though she was keeping an appropriate social distance, and calling out to her nastily to “pick up her feet” and “stop shuffling.” The older woman ignored them. And I was afraid to intervene for fear the men would turn their anger on me. What should I have done?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Laura Cappelle
title: Poems! Songs! Demands! It’s Not Theater, but It’s … Something
description: Performing-arts protesters locked out by the pandemic have occupied playhouses across France, but drama is not allowed. Cue the “agoras.”
content: Dozens of French theater workers walk into a room and occupy it. What happens next? A month later, not nearly as many performances as you might expect.
source.name: The New York Times

title: The T List: Five Things We Recommend This Week
description: Charlotte Mensah’s beauty routine, drawings by David Hockney — and more.
content: Welcome to the T List, a newsletter from the editors of T Magazine. Each week, we share things we’re eating, wearing, listening to or coveting now. Sign up here to find us in your inbox every Wednesday. And you can always reach us at tlist@nytimes.com.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Eavis and Matthew Haag
title: After Pandemic, Shrinking Need for Office Space Could Crush Landlords
description: Some big employers are giving up square footage as they juggle remote work. That could devastate building owners and cities.
content: As office vacancies climb to their highest levels in decades with businesses giving up office space and embracing remote work, the real estate industry in many American cities faces a potentially grave threat.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs
title: George Floyd showed signs of a brain injury 4 minutes before Derek Chauvin lifted his knee, a doctor testifies.
description: Dr. Martin J. Tobin, a lung expert, said Mr. Floyd died of “a low level of oxygen” caused in part by Mr. Chauvin’s pressure, and that fentanyl did not have an effect on Mr. Floyd’s breathing before he lost consciousness.
content: A veteran lung doctor testified on Thursday that George Floyd’s death was caused in part by Derek Chauvin’s knees pressing against his neck and back, making it impossible for him to breathe, and that Mr. Floyd showed signs of a brain injury about four minutes before Mr. Chauvin lifted his knee from his neck.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Raymond Zhong and Amy Chang Chien
title: Drought in Taiwan Pits Chip Makers Against Farmers
description: The island is going to great lengths to keep water flowing to its all-important semiconductor industry, including shutting off irrigation to legions of rice growers.
content: HSINCHU, Taiwan — Chuang Cheng-deng’s modest rice farm is a stone’s throw from the nerve center of Taiwan’s computer chip industry, whose products power a huge share of the world’s iPhones and other gadgets.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Futterman
title: Olympic Bobsledder Who Killed Himself Likely Had C.T.E.
description: Pavle Jovanovic, who represented the United States at the 2006 Olympics, is believed to be the first athlete in a sliding sport to be found with a disease caused by repeated brain traumas.
content: A former Olympic bobsledder who killed himself last year had chronic traumatic encephalopathy, or C.T.E., researchers concluded, the same degenerative brain disease that has been found in former football players and other athletes who participated in violent contact sports.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julian E. Barnes
title: U.S. Intelligence Report Warns of Global Consequences of Social Fragmentation
description: The coronavirus pandemic has highlighted weaknesses of the international order, said the report, which is issued every four years.
content: WASHINGTON — U.S. intelligence officials warned in a report issued on Thursday about the potential fragmentation of society and the global order, holding out the possibility of a world where international trade is disrupted, groups of countries create online enclaves and civic cohesion is undermined.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rachel Nuwer
title: As Locusts Swarmed East Africa, This Tech Helped Squash Them
description: A hastily formed crowdsourcing operation to contain the insects in Kenya, Ethiopia and Somalia could help manage climate-related disasters everywhere.
content: Melodine Jeptoo will never forget the first time she saw a locust swarm. Moving like a dark cloud, the insects blotted out the sky and pelted her like hail.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Brooks
title: The Heart and Soul of the Biden Project
description: It’s a daring revival of “the American System.”
content: What is the quintessential American act? It is the leap of faith. The first European settlers left the comfort of their old countries and migrated to brutal conditions, convinced the future would be better on this continent. Immigrants all crossed oceans or wilderness to someplace they didn’t know, hoping that their children would someday breathe the atmosphere of prosperity and freedom.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Karni
title: Biden Takes Initial Steps to Address Gun Violence
description: With legislation in Congress stalled by Republican opposition, the president ordered a crackdown on “ghost guns” and said the epidemic of shootings was “an international embarrassment.”
content: WASHINGTON — President Biden, calling gun violence in the United States “an international embarrassment,” took a set of initial steps on Thursday to address the problem, starting with a crackdown on the proliferation of so-called ghost guns, or firearms assembled from kits.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marie Fazio
title: Dr. Martin J. Tobin, a pulmonologist, says shallow breathing led to George Floyd’s death.
description: During his testimony, Dr. Tobin said that several things — Mr. Floyd’s prone position, his being handcuffed, and having a knee on his neck and back — contributed to his shallow breathing.
content: Dr. Martin J. Tobin, a pulmonologist and critical care physician from the Chicago area, was the first witness prosecutors called to the stand in the Derek Chauvin trial on Thursday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Teo Bugbee
title: ‘Slalom’ Review: First, Abuse, Then a Steep Downhill
description: This French drama from Charlène Favier presents a sensitive and discomforting view of sexual abuse within alpine sports.
content: In competitive skiing, athletes balance the rewards of downhill glory against the dangers of a fall. The sensitive, discomforting drama “Slalom” follows Lyz (Noée Abita), a 15-year-old recruit to a ski facility in the French Alps. There, young skiers are molded into champions by an ambitious trainer, Fred (Jérémie Renier).
source.name: The New York Times

title: For Bonds, Add Safety by Venturing Abroad

content: Making your bond-fund portfolio less risky requires doing something that can feel like living dangerously: investing abroad.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Scott Heller
title: Williamstown Festival Will Take the Shows Outside
description: After a lost live 2020, the theater will stage a musical at a museum’s reflecting pool and an immersive show, all over town, based on real events.
content: The Williamstown Theater Festival, which was forced by the pandemic to convert its 2020 season into a series of audio plays, will present live performances again this summer, though not in its indoor venues.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jessica Schiffer
title: How Barely-There Botox Became the Norm

content: Forget what you think you know about Botox. Once considered the not-so-secret tool of celebrities and the wealthy with a bad rap for freezing faces, the wrinkle-melting injections have become a commonplace activity of a normie class with money to spare.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Doctor and His Grandchildren Among 5 Fatally Shot in South Carolina
description: The victims included the doctor’s wife and two of their eight grandchildren. The gunman, identified as a former N.F.L. cornerback, was found dead at a nearby home.
content: A neighbor shot and killed a doctor, the doctor’s wife and their two grandchildren inside their house in Rock Hill, S.C., as well as an air-conditioning technician who was working outside the home on Wednesday afternoon, the authorities said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chris Vognar
title: ‘Worn Stories’ Treats Clothing as the Fabric of Memory. I Can Relate.
description: Inspired by the new Netflix documentary series, a writer takes a journey through his own closet as a means of processing grief.
content: For Joe, it’s the Air Jordan hoodie that belonged to his son, Jeremy, cut down by a lethal heroin overdose. For the writer and stylist Simon Doonan, it’s a pair of Lycra Stephen Sprouse leggings, worn through sweaty aerobics classes to cope as one friend after another died of AIDS. For Michael, it’s the patchwork quilt sewed by his mom, Debbie, while she was in prison.
source.name: The New York Times

source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Libbey
title: The Church, an Arts Center in Sag Harbor, Is Opening

title: ‘Moffie’ Review: A Bleak Coming-of-Age

content: From the mid-1960s to 1990, South Africa not only imposed apartheid but in a sense exported it. Starting at age 16, white South African boys went through a period of mandatory military service.

author: By Kristen Yoonsoo Kim
title: ‘The Power’ Review: Night Terrors During a London Blackout
description: The writer and director Corinna Faith doesn’t wait for the lights to dim to unleash a creaky, eerie atmosphere.
content: In 1970s Britain, as the government and trade unions were warring, blackouts were regularly ordered to conserve power. During one of these pitch-black nights, a timid young woman named Val (Rose Williams) finds herself working the dark shift on her first day of duty as a trainee nurse at a run-down London hospital. The writer and director Corinna Faith doesn’t wait for the lights to dim to unleash the uneasiness in “The Power.” The creaky, eerie atmosphere is felt even in daylight as Val starts to hear children’s indecipherable whispers. “A place people die in should never be allowed to get that dark,” one nurse says, anxiously building up the frights to come, which work to a mixed degree.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Jason Karaian, Sarah Kessler, Michael J. de la Merced, Lauren Hirsch and Ephrat Livni
title: A Tax Change Is Coming, Maybe
description: President Biden unveils his corporate tax overhaul.

But it has also opened some new opportunities thanks to the expansion of video technology and remote work, which employers are now embracing. Demand for new homes is spiking around the country, and many at-home workers, unbound from their commutes, are free to consider moving anywhere that fits their budget.

description: And their decline has led to a steep drop in tax rates for the affluent.
content: The main cause of the radical decline in tax rates for very wealthy Americans over the past 75 years isn’t the one that many people would guess. It’s not about lower income taxes (though they certainly play a role), and it’s not about lower estate taxes (though they matter too).

content: You want Yusef Komunyakaa to write your poems for you. A Pulitzer Prize-winning poet, Komunyakaa has mastered the ability to turn the mundane into memorable. I remember reading this cat in prison wondering how he even conjured up the title “Neon Vernacular” or “Talking Dirty to the Gods.” His latest, “Everyday Mojo Songs of Earth,” gives us some classics.
